questions.text: The fundoscopy findings of a known case of HIV with low CD4 counts in shown below. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ganciclovir

The above image depicts “sauce and cheese” retinopathy, which is characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis, Ganciclovir is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient comes to the OPD with complaints of visual disturbances. On fundoscopy, multiple flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and disc edema were found. What is the grade of hypertensive retinopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Grade IV

Cotton wool spots and flame shaped hemorrage with disc edema is seen in grade IV of hypertensive retinopathy.

questions.text: A child presented to the OPD with a characteristic type of cataract as seen in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Galactosemia

The image shown below shows an oil drop cataract seen in galactosemia. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency leads to classical galactosemia which is an autosomal recessive disorder.

questions.text: An 86-year-old man is posted for cataract surgery. The given lens is chosen to be used for implantation. Identify the lens.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Posterior chamber IOL 

The above image depicts a modified C-loop type of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL).

choices.text: Immature senile cataract and phacoemulsification with IOL

questions.text: A 68-year-old diabetic woman presents with painless loss of vision. The ocular findings are shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis and management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Immature senile cataract and phacoemulsification with IOL

The given clinical scenario and the above image are suggestive of an immature senile cataract and the appropriate treatment is phacoemulsification with posterior intraocular lens implantation.
An immature senile cataract is characterized by partial opacification of the lens. The cuneiform and cupuliform patterns of opacification are seen and the lens appears greyish-white. Iris shadow is visible. Slit-lamp examination shows areas of the normal and cataractous cortex.

questions.text: The following finding is found on the ophthalmologic examination of a 19-year-old boy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Myotonic dystrophy

The above image characteristically depicts a Christmas tree cataract. Myotonic dystrophy is associated with Christmas tree cataracts and salt and pepper fundus.

questions.text: At a routine ophthalmological check-up, a patient was found to have bilateral, Y-shaped lens opacities as shown below. He was diagnosed with suture cataracts. Which zone of the lens nucleus is not involved here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The primary fibers in the fetal nucleus of the lens do not form Y-shaped sutures.

The image shows bilateral cataracts in the Y-shaped sutures of the lens. These are very slowly progressive congenital cataracts and do not require any surgical intervention.

questions.text: What does the given fundoscopic picture suggest?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Glaucomatous optic atrophy

The given fundoscopic image clearly depicts cupping. Thinning of the neuroretinal rim, and splinter hemarrage of optic disc

questions.text: A 36-year-old male comes to you with the complaints of foreign body sensation, irritation, and lacrimation in the right eye. During the evaluation, you notice the following findings with normal lid margins. This condition is known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Trichiasis

The given image is suggestive of Trichiasis.

Trichiasis refers to inward misdirection of cilia, which usually rub against the eyeball with the normal position of the lid margin. These patients present with foreign body sensation and photophobia. They experience troublesome irritation, pain, and lacrimation. On examination, one or more misdirected cilia touching the cornea is seen. Conjunctiva may be congested

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl you examine in an outreach camp is found to have this abnormality. What is the most common site of the condition seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Inferonasal

The condition depicted in the image is a coloboma of the iris, and the most common site of coloboma is the inferonasal quadrant.

A coloboma is a congenital malformation in one of the structures in the eye such as the iris, retina, choroid, or optic disc due to the failure of embryonic fissure closure.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of shown instrument?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Binocular vision

Indirect ophthalmoscope needs a binocular vision.

questions.text: Identify the chart given in the picture below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hess chart 

The chart given in the picture is Hess’s chart.

Hess chart is used to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus by assessing the field of a binocular single vision. In its interpretation, a smaller chart indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart Indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.

questions.text: A neonate is brought with complaints of photophobia and watering. Clinical examination shows normal tear passages and clear but large cornea. Investigation reveals Haab’s striae seen in the eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Buphthalmos

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of buphthalmos. Haab’s striae are horizontal/circumferential breaks in Descemet’s membrane seen in buphthalmos. Buphthalmos (Bull-like eyes) is an enlargement of the eyeball seen in true congenital and infantile glaucoma, usually when the disease onset is before 3 years.

questions.text: Deposition of which of the following is responsible for band-shaped keratopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Calcium

Band-shaped keratopathy is caused by pathological calcium deposition on the cornea in the form of a band.

On exam, there is a white band-like formation of calcium across the corneal surface with irregular borders and a peripheral clearing of cornea between the calcium deposits and the limbus. The calcium deposition is typically found beneath the epithelial layer within Bowman’s layer but may extend into the anterior stroma.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with anhidrosis and enophthalmos. Examination reveals miosis along with mild ptosis as shown in the below image. You decide to correct the ptosis by performing Fasanella-Servat operation, by resecting which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Muller’s muscle

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner’s syndrome and the associated mild ptosis in this condition can be corrected by resecting Muller’s muscle.
Ptosis in Horner’s syndrome is due to the paralysis of Muller’s muscle.

Fasanella-Servat operation is indicated in cases having mild ptosis(<2 mm) and good levator function. In this surgery, the upper tarsal border along with its attached Muller’s muscle and conjunctiva are resected.

questions.text: A 2-month-old girl child was brought to the hospital by her parents with the following presentation. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Immediate surgery

For the 2-month-old girl presenting with leukocoria in the left eye, likely indicative of a congenital infantile cataract, immediate surgery is the most appropriate management. Congenital infantile cataract refers to lens opacities present at birth, which can obstruct vision and potentially affect the child’s overall development. If left untreated, congenital cataracts, especially unilateral cataracts, can lead to amblyopia, a condition where one eye fails to develop normal vision due to insufficient visual input.

questions.text: Identify the defect shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Herbert pits

The image shows tiny lesions at the limbus, indicating Hebert’s pits. This finding is seen in trachoma, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, more specifically the trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis (TRIC) serovars A, B, Ba, C.

questions.text: An 12-year-old presented with the following growth in the eye as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Limbal dermoid

The image shows the presence of a limbal dermoid.

Limbal Dermoid is a choristoma (a mass of histologically normal tissue in an abnormal location). It consists of collagenous tissue containing dermal elements and covered by stratified squamous epithelium. Limbal dermoid present in early childhood as a subconjunctival mass in the infratemporal limbus. Treatment is indicated for chronic irritation, amblyopia, vision impairment and corneal dellen formation. Small dermoids can be excised, larger lesions may need lamellar keratosclerectomy.

questions.text: Identify the visual field defect in the given image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Homonymous hemianopia

The visual field defect in the given image is the right homonymous hemianopia.

Right homonymous hemianopia, marked by loss of vision in the right half of the visual field of both eyes, indicates a lesion in the left optic tract. This occurs because the optic tract transmits visual information from the left nasal retina and right temporal retina, and disruption leads to right-sided visual field loss
